Award.AwardTitle: Biological Mechanisms for Exploiting Resonance in Undulatory Swimming

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of the proposed project is to understand whether and how neuronal control circuits exploit mechanical resonance during animal locomotion to achieve highly efficient rhythmic body movements. General principles will be uncovered through a specific case study of dynamical mechanisms underlying undulatory swimming of leeches. Diverse behaviors of leeches are generated by relatively simple neuronal circuits, providing a unique opportunity for preliminary understanding of how the brain works in the most primitive form. A simple integrated model of leech swimming, amenable to analytical studies, will be developed from detailed, experimentally validated, component models of the neuronal circuit, motoneuron activation, muscle biomechanics, and body-fluid interactions. Theoretical and computational studies of the model will then be performed to examine how the neural control circuits process sensory signals and achieve oscillations near a resonance under nominal and perturbed environmental conditions.

Once uncovered, resonance entrainment principles will contribute to understanding of general complex systems that achieve robustness, adaptability, and emergence. These new functionalities, when engineered, will have a broad range of applications, including robotic vehicles that maintain efficiency of transportation under varying environments. In the medical field, understanding of the neural control mechanisms is fundamental to determining the cause, rehabilitation, and cure for loss or reduction of locomotor ability due to neurological disorders or spinal cord injury. The research activities are integrated into educational activities at both K-12 and college levels. A graduate student will be trained for experimental data processing and model-based dynamical systems analyses. Through research experience activities, undergraduate students will develop educational software modules for simulation/animation of leech swimming to stimulate K-12 students' curiosity for science/engineering during such occasions as Engineering Open House. The results will be broadly disseminated to both biology and control engineering communities to enhance cross-cultural fertilization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During animal locomotion such as walking, swimming, and flying, the body goes through a rhythmic movement. The cycle frequency of the movement seems to depend on the size of individual animals. For instance, bees flap much faster than hawks, and elephants walk with a much slower pace than ants. Scientists have hypothesized that the choices for the frequency are made to maximize the locomotion efficiency by exploiting a resonance. The resonance is a common phenomenon observed for an oscillating body where a large-amplitude oscillation is produced with a small-amplitude force input at a particular frequency intrinsic to the body. While it is well studied for certain mechanical systems, the resonance is less understood or even undefined in the context of locomotion where a large amplitude oscillation of the body does not necessarily imply effective propulsion. For locomotion, not only the frequency but also the shape of body oscillation are important.

The project has attempted to elucidate mechanisms by which animals choose a particular frequency and shape of the body oscillation. Scientific challenges posed by animal locomotion in general were addressed through focused studies of medicinal leech swimming for which details of its physiology and neural circuits are largely known and await dynamical systems analyses to provide deeper understanding. The project developed a mathematical model of swimming leeches with validation against experimental data, and ordinary differential equations described how the undulatory body movement results from muscle contraction and hydrodynamic forces from the surrounding fluid. The main finding of the project is a formal definition of the "natural gait" by which undulatory motions observed in leeches can be explained. The body shape of the natural gait is defined by the free motion of an idealized body (massless, frictionless, completely flexible ribbon) flattering in a flow of water. The frequency and amplitude of the natural gait are defined by the body-fluid resonance that maximizes the ratio of the swim speed to the muscle bending moment. The natural gaits, calculated from the model with parameter values set from five leeches of varying sizes, were found to match reasonably well with experimentally observed gaits of those leeches.

The intellectual merit of the project is the following. The result contributed to advancing scientific knowledge on how animals move naturally. The observed motion of leech swimming was explained by formally defined concepts of natural oscillation and resonance. It was found that the shape of body oscillation conforms to the dynamical constraints imposed by the environment (fluid), and the cycle frequency of oscillation is chosen to minimize the effort required to achieve a given task (swimming). The concept of natural gait, derived from the particular example of leech swimming, will be applicable to other animals through proper generalizations guided by dynamical systems theories. The broader impacts of the project include the result that provides a systematic guideline for bio-inspired design of engineered systems. In particular, the natural gait theory suggests how the motion of autonomous robotic locomotors can be determined to exploit the natural dynamics and maximize the efficiency. Moreover, the result would be useful for motion planning of mechanical devices that interact with humans, such as wearable robots for walking rehabilitation, since it is critical to ensure that the robotic motion is perceived by human as natural. More generally, the project outcome will contribute to the foundation of complex systems design to achieve robustness, adaptivity, autonomy, and emergence. Addition of these functionalities to engineered systems would bring a new perspective for improving the quality of life.
